AC/DC tries hard but stumbles on 'Rock or Bust'

AC/DC tries hard but stumbles on 'Rock or Bust,' its first album without Malcolm Young.

AC/DC tries hard but stumbles on 'Rock or Bust'

Jeffrey Lee Puckett, jpuckett@courier-journal.com 4:58 p.m. EST December 2, 2014

CONNECT 5 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

AC/DC, 'Rock or Bust'

These are not carefree times for AC/DC, a band built for nothing but carefree times. Founding member Malcolm Young is gone, the master of bone-crushing riffage forced into retirement by dementia. Drummer Phil Rudd has apparently lost his mind and will likely be replaced even if he survives charges of threatening to have someone killed.

And yet they soldier on, definitely lesser for the absence of Young but still showing flashes of the band that has defined rock 'n' roll for generations of beer drinkers and head bangers. Just not quite enough flashes. On the band's 15th album, there are moments where the music almost takes off but ultimately it all sounds like the work of dedicated, talented pros rather than men driven by inspiration.

COURIER-JOURNAL

AC/DC is 'Rock or Bust' without Malcolm Young, who retired this year due to complication from dementia.

Angus Young tabbed his nephew, Stevie, to take over for his brother and pieced together 11 songs from older, unfinished material written with Malcolm outtakes, in other words, stuff not quite good enough for past records. All of the familiar pieces are in play and none of the songs are bad it's crucial that singer Brian Johnson sounds so great but the band never delivers that rush of visceral energy so common in the past.

AC/DC has long been a machine, each piece fitted perfectly to the next, and "Rock or Bust" makes it clear that Malcolm made the machine hum.

Jeffrey Lee Puckett, The Courier-Journal


Jeffrey Lee and Tom duke it out in the basement this week over their Top 10 favorites from AC/DC. Scott Utterback, The Courier-Journal
